panels.description: Shows the latest log lines from the service. Use this to correlate metrics spikes with specific application events (like errors or slow queries) in real-time.
panels.title: Recent Activity Log

panels.description: Tracks the 95th percentile latency (in milliseconds) for each API endpoint. This shows the "worst-case" experience for 95% of users and is the standard for monitoring performance and spotting slowdowns.
panels.title: p95 Latency by Endpoint

panels.description: Shows the requests per second for each individual API endpoint (route). This is used to identify the most popular or "hot" endpoints in the application.
panels.title: Request Rate by Endpoint

panels.description: Tracks the percentage of total requests that are failing with a 5xx server-side error (e.g., 500, 503). This is a critical indicator of service health and reliability.
panels.title: Server Error Rate (5xx %)

panels.description: Tracks the total number of incoming HTTP requests per second (RPS) for the entire service. This is the main "heartbeat" of the application, showing overall traffic volume.
panels.title: Total Request Rate

panels.description: Breaks down the total request rate by HTTP method (GET, POST, PUT, etc.). This visualization is stacked to show the "shape" of the traffic (e.g., read-heavy vs. write-heavy)
panels.title: Request Rate by Method

panels.description: A real-time count of unique users who have made a request to the service within the last 5 minutes. This is a "heartbeat" for current user engagement.
panels.title: Users Online (Last 5 Mins)

panels.description: Tracks the total number of unique, authenticated users who have used the service at least once during a 24-hour period. This graph shows the long-term trend of user growth and engagement.
panels.title: Daily Active Users (DAU)

panels.description: The ratio of Daily Active Users to Monthly Active Users. A higher percentage means users are more "sticky" and return frequently. This is a key indicator of product-market fit.
panels.title: Stickiness (DAU/MAU Ratio)

panels.description: Tracks the total number of requests per second (RPS) to the authentication endpoint (e.g., /api/auth). This shows the overall load on the auth service.
panels.title: Authentication Attempt Rate

panels.description: Tracks the rate of successful (2xx) vs. failed (4xx) authentication attempts. A sudden spike in failures can indicate a brute-force attack or a broken login form.
panels.title: Auth Success vs. Failure Rate

panels.description: Tracks the percentage of total authentication attempts that are successful. A sudden drop in this rate is a strong indicator of a service problem.
panels.title: Authentication Success Rate %

panels.description: Tracks the average CPU load of the Node.js application, calculated across all running containers. This shows the typical CPU footprint of the app itself, separate from the total system load. It's useful for spotting general increases in application processing.
panels.title: Average App CPU Usage %

panels.description: Tracks the CPU utilization of the *single busiest* Node.js process at any given moment. This graph is critical for spotting "hot containers"—an app process stuck in a 100% CPU loop, for example—which would be hidden by the 'Average' CPU graph.
panels.title: Max App CPU Usage % (per Container)

panels.description: Tracks the total number of CPU cores used by all Node.js processes combined (a sum, not an average). This graph shows the total CPU demand of the entire service on the infrastructure, which is a key metric for capacity planning.
panels.title: Total App CPU Usage (Cores)

panels.description: Tracks the *average* memory (RAM) used by a single Node.js process, calculated across all running containers. This graph shows the typical memory footprint of the app. It's used to spot general trends, but it can hide memory leaks in a single bad container.
panels.title: Average App Memory (per Container)

panels.description: Tracks the memory usage of the *single worst-performing* container at any given moment. This graph is critical for spotting individual container memory leaks or out-of-memory issues, which are often hidden by the 'Average' memory graph.
panels.title: Max App Memory (Hot Container)

panels.description: Tracks the *total sum* of memory (RAM) used by every running container combined. This graph shows the complete memory footprint of the entire service on the infrastructure. It's useful for high-level capacity planning and understanding total resource consumption as the service scales.
panels.title: Total App Memory Footprint

panels.description: Tracks the average CPU utilization (as a percentage) across all running containers. This shows the typical, overall CPU load on the fleet, but it can hide problems in a single busy container.
panels.title: Average System CPU % (per Container)

panels.description: Shows the CPU utilization of the *single busiest container* (the one with the least idle time). This is critical for spotting "hot" containers where a process (like the app or a sidecar) is at its limit, even if the average looks good.
panels.title: Max System CPU % (Hot Container)

panels.description: Tracks the total number of CPU cores being consumed by the *entire service* (all containers combined). This shows the service's total CPU demand on the infrastructure and is useful for high-level capacity planning and cost analysis.
panels.title: Total System CPU (Cores)

panels.description: Tracks the average memory utilization (as a percentage of the container's limit) across all running containers. This shows the typical, overall memory pressure on the fleet.
panels.title: Average System Memory % (per Container)

panels.description: Shows the memory utilization of the *single most-used container*. This is the most critical graph for spotting containers that are close to their memory limit and are at risk of being killed (OOMKilled) by the scheduler.
panels.title: Max System Memory % (OOM Detector)

panels.description: Tracks the *total sum* of absolute memory (in GB/MB) used by all containers combined. This shows the complete memory footprint of the entire service, which is useful for capacity planning.
panels.title: Total System Memory Footprint

panels.description: Tracks the number of *individual pizzas* sold, based on the quantity from each successful order. This is a custom business metric.
panels.title: Pizzas Sold (Cumulative)

panels.description: Tracks the amount of "bitcoin" revenue from successful orders. This is a custom business metric.
panels.title: Revenue Bitcoin (Cumulative)

panels.description: Tracks the number of incoming POST requests to the order creation endpoint. This shows the overall traffic for users starting the pizza creation process.
panels.title: Order Attempts (Cumulative)

panels.description: Tracks the rate of *individual pizzas* sold, based on the quantity from each successful order. This is a custom business metric.
panels.title: Pizzas Sold Rate (per Second)

panels.description: Tracks the rate of "bitcoin" revenue from successful orders. This is a custom business metric.
panels.title: Revenue Rate (per Second)

panels.description: Tracks the rate of incoming POST requests to the order creation endpoint. This shows the overall traffic for users starting the pizza creation process.
panels.title: Order Attempt Rate (per Second)

panels.description: Tracks the 95th percentile latency (in ms) for the outbound call to the 3rd party pizza factory. A spike here means the external factory is slow.
panels.title: Pizza Factory API Latency (p95)

panels.description: Tracks the percentage of outbound requests to the pizza factory that returned a successful 2xx status code. This is a direct measure of the factory's reliability.
panels.title: Pizza Factory Success Rate %

panels.description: Tracks the 95th percentile latency (in milliseconds) for *all* incoming requests. This shows the typical "worst-case" experience for 95% of users and is a key indicator of overall service health.
panels.title: Overall p95 Latency

panels.description: Tracks the 95th percentile latency for each individual API endpoint. This is used to identify specific slow routes (e.g., a slow /api/order) that might be hidden by the overall average.
panels.title: p95 Latency by Endpoint

panels.description: Visualizes the full distribution of request latencies over time. The Y-axis shows the latency (e.g., 100ms, 500ms), and the color intensity shows how many requests fell into that bucket at that specific time.
panels.title: Request Latency Distribution (Heatmap)
